sentence: The main stock markets in the U.S. gained on Wednesday, with all three benchmarks just managing to pull ahead as the Nasdaq Composite closed at the highest level since April 18 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average reversed earlier losses.
More mixed economic data seemed to keep the indexes fluctuating through much of the session and treading water before key jobs data later in the week.
Of the 30 blue chips, 17 traded higher, led by E. I. du Pont de Nemours ( DD ), while six of the S&P 500's 10 industry sectors were stronger, driven by a 0.6% gain in consumer staples.
Telecommunications services were down 0.9%, the steepest decline among the groups.
The final May manufacturing PMI was revised up to 50.7 from 50.5 initially, but down from April's 50.8.
Construction spending fell 1.8% in April, missing estimates for a modest 0.6% gain.
The Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index rose to 51.3 in May from 50.8 the month prior, beating estimates for a decline to 50.6.

Oil futures were also just higher by the end of the regular session, with US crude up 0.2% after spending much of the day losing ground as Reuters cited sources as saying countries who are members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) are likely to consider a production cap during a meeting on Thursday.
Also on the calendar for Thursday is the May ADP private payrolls estimate at 8:15 a.m.
ET and initial weekly jobless claims at 8:30 a.m. Payrolls and the unemployment rate for May will be released on Friday.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) DWRE (+55.89%) To be acquired by Salesforce ( CRM ) for $2.8 billion

(+) GALE (+19.34%) Gets FDA fast track status for NeuVax to treat breast cancer

(+) LULU (+1.75%) Founder Wilson calls for changes in board member voting
